title: Press selection list for Afghan newspapers 20 Feb 19
snippet:
Newspapers published in Kabul

Hasht-e Sobh (independent)
body:
1. Editorial entitled "Evil India-centred security policy" condemns the remark by the Pakistani ambassador to Kabul who yesterday said India's possible attack on Pakistan would probably harm the Afghan peace process. It describes Pakistan's long-lasting hostility with India as a big factor behind the prolongation of the Afghan conflict, and stresses that the Pakistani army should no longer pursue its anti-India policy towards Afghanistan. (p 2, about 650 words in Dari, PROCESSING)

2. Article by Hussein Haidari entitled "Best toilet paper in world; Google says it is Pakistan's flag" (p 8, about 1,200 words in Dari, NPP)

3. Article by Shamshad Aziz Kazemi entitled "Rules and art of intelligence war" (p 6, about 2,000 words in Dari, NPP)

4. Article by Ferdaus entitled "What should Presidential Palace finally do?" comments on US special envoy for Afghanistan reconciliation Zalmay Khalilzad's recent statement saying the Afghan government should form a negotiating team that should be comprised of government officials and political personalities. It is not sure whether the presidential office will accept Khalilzad's demand, and stresses that no effort should be made to establish an interim government in Afghanistan. (p 4, about 1,200 words in Dari, NPP)

5. Article by Musaver Zadfar entitled "Afghan students' difficulties in Kazakhstan; from poverty to lack of health insurance" urges the Afghan government to take action to solve the problems of the Afghans who are studying in Kazakhstan with a lot of difficulties. (p 5, about 1,200 words in Dari, NPP)

Mandegar (private)

1. Editorial entitled "ATRA does not take care" opposes the deduction of 10 per cent of people's credit cards by the Afghan government, and says there is no-one to address people's concerns and doubts about extensive fraud and corruption in the Ministry of Telecommunication. It urges Afghanistan Telecom Regulatory Authority or ATRA to hold talks with officials of communication companies and ask them why people's complaints about embezzlement are overlooked. (p 2, about 800 words in Dari, NPP)

2. Unattributed article entitled "ATRA does not take action" criticises Afghanistan Telecom Regulatory Authority or ATRA for not supervising communication companies' activities in the country, saying a large number of people are fed up with poor communication services. It urges ATRA to discharge its duties and responsibilities appropriately. (p 3, about 1,800 words in Dari, NPP)

3. Article by Rahmat Ahmadi entitled "How did Sardar manage to escape from Taliban?" tells the story of an Afghan army soldier named Sardar Mohammad who managed to escape a Taliban-held area after being harassed and tormented by the militants. (p 6, about 2,000 words in Dari, NPP)

4. Article by Ahmad Emran entitled "Inappropriate mechanism for electing election commissioners" claims with confidence that the National Unity Government will be unable to hold the next presidential and provincial council elections in a transparent and free manner, saying the process of electing new commissioners for the election commissioners needs enough time and accuracy. (p 2, about 1,200 words in Dari, NPP)

Weesa (private)

1. Editorial entitled "Why Pakistan threatens peace?" comments on Pakistani ambassador to Kabul Nasrullah Zahid's statement that the current India-Pakistan dispute will adversely affect the Afghan peace process, saying there is no doubt that Pakistan has the ability to play with Afghanistan's future for many more years. It argues that the US and Pakistan have stricken a dangerous deal over the Afghan peace. (p 2, about 550 words in Pashto, PROCESSING)

2. Article by Ustad Mohammad Zaman Muzamil entitled "Moscow and few impacts" describes the recent two-day Moscow conference on Afghanistan's future as a sign of establishment of a possible sustainable peace in Afghanistan. It says the matter of pleasure is that former warlords and political personalities held talks with senior Taliban officials for the first time during the past 18 years. (p 3, about 1,600 words in Pashto, NPP)

3. Article by Aziz Chopan entitled "Beyond Afghan peace, US and Pakistan searching for own interests" argues that the Taliban group has been suffering from internal differences during the past several years, saying a number of militant leaders are unable to do anything without Pakistan's permission. It claims with confidence that Saudi Arabia's recent generous financial support for Pakistan took place at the US's behest. (pp 1, 4, about 2,000 words in Pashto, NPP)

4. Article by Strategic Centre for Regional Studies entitled "Amending election law, step towards transparency in elections" hails the Afghan government for dismissing all the commissioners of the Independent Election Commission and the Electoral Complaints Commission. It gives an assurance that the next presidential elections will be held in a transparent, free, fair, and credible manner as it says the election system has been amended properly. (pp 2, 4, about 2,000 words in Dari, NPP)

Arman-e Melli (close to the National Union of Journalists of Afghanistan)

1. Editorial entitled "Consultative grand assembly should also discuss continuation of president's work after 1st of Jawza" urges Afghan leaders to make sure they accept all the decisions of a consultative or traditional grand assembly due to be convened in Kabul next month. It stresses that the participants of the assembly should not allow Ghani to continue work as the country's president after the 1st of Jawza (third solar month). (p 2, about 600 words in Dari, PROCESSING)

2. Article by Noorullah Walizada entitled "Does Khalilzad make diplomatic efforts or has already reached agreement with government?" warns that if Afghan leaders continue to oppose peace talks with the Taliban, Afghanistan will experience a bloodier conflict in the coming few years. It describes Zalmay Khalilzad's peace efforts as unsuccessful, and says that Qatar was behind the cancellation of a Taliban delegation's Pakistan visit. (p 3, about 1,600 words in Dari, NPP)

3. Article by Sayed Hussein Hadi entitled "Taliban from being a terrorist group to becoming a powerful political opponent" endorses the allegation that the Taliban want to take control of Afghanistan after a possible withdrawal of the coalition forces, saying the Afghan government should not have pursued a policy of appeasement to the militant group during the past 18 years. It accuses Iran, Pakistan, Russia, and China of playing a role in prolonging the Afghan conflict. (p 4, about 1,800 words in Dari, NPP)

4. Article by Ahmad Sayidi entitled "From Soviet withdrawal to rumours about US withdrawal; which positive development visible in Afghanistan?" describes the presence of the coalition forces in Afghanistan as detrimental to ordinary Afghans, saying insecurity has spread to all parts of the country and poverty and unemployment have peaked due to the US's policy of leniency towards the Taliban. (p 2, about 1,200 words in Dari, NPP)

The Daily Afghanistan (private)

1. Editorial by Mohammad Hedayat entitled "Discrimination convicted by all means" condemns the Afghan government's decision to absorb students to universities and other academic institution based on ethnic size. It stresses that intelligent students regardless of their ethnicities should be paid greater attention so that ethnic discrimination is tackled to a great extent. (p 2, about 900 words in Dari, EXCERPT 500 words)

2. Article by Sayed Amin Behzad entitled "Cooperation between Riyadh and Islamabad leads to growth of religious extremism in region" criticises Saudi Arabia for providing generous financial support to Pakistan at a time when the latter is accused of supporting dangerous militant groups in Afghanistan, India and Iran. It argues that it is Saudi Arabia that has been financing and sponsoring a majority of religious schools in Pakistan. (p 3, about 1,600 words in Dari, NPP)

3. Article by Mohammad Salem Naji entitled "Intra-Afghan talks on regional dispute" accuses the US, Russia, and China of searching for their interests in the prolongation and escalation of the Afghan war, saying no regional country has yet taken effective and practical measures to establish sustainable peace and stability in Afghanistan. It calls on Iran and Saudi Arabia not to pursue their political rivalries in Afghanistan anymore. (p 3, about 1,600 words in Dari, NPP)

4. Article by Hadi Rahimizada entitled "Peace process; Saudi Arabia and Afghanistan's diplomacy" calls on the Afghan government to expand its political relations with Saudi Arabia and other powerful Arab countries in an attempt to gain their support for the peace process. It claims with confidence that Pakistan will be in a great economic trouble if Saudi Arabia stops supporting it. (p 2, about 900 words in Dari, NPP)

Eslah (state-run)

1. Editorial entitled "Pakistan should be forced to cooperate honestly with Afghan peace process" praises Zalmay Khalilzad for asking Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammad Bin Salman to support Pakistan in case it reins in terrorism and puts pressure on the Taliban to hold direct talks with the Afghan government. It argues that Pakistan not only supports insurgency in Afghanistan but it also sends insurgents to India and Iran for carrying out subversive moves. (pp 1, 5, about 1,200 words in Dari, EXCERPT 600 words)

2. Article by Payenda entitled "Agreement over implementation of new strategy will lead to consensus on peace talks" gives an assurance that peace talks with the Taliban will prove effective if the Afghan government forms a comprehensive negotiating team that should be comprised of political personalities, civil activists and government officials. (p 3, about 2,000 words in Dari, NPP)

3. Article by Shah Mahmood Darwesh entitled "Our country's economic growth and development need constructive measures" urges the Afghan government to take action to expand its economic and trade relations with powerful regional countries, especially China and India. (p 4, about 700 words in Pashto, NPP)

4. Article by Paiman Nazari entitled "Islamabad welcomes Saudi Arabian Crown Prince in unprecedented manner; what is Pakistan searching for?" criticises Saudi Arabia for its generous financial support for Pakistan. It claims with confidence that terrorism and extremism will become stronger in the region with the passing of every day if Pakistan does not come under immense economic, political, and military pressures. (p 2, about 1,000 words in Dari, NPP)

Hewad (state-run)

1. Editorial entitled "What is base of Taliban-Pakistan relations?" calls on Pakistan to define its long-standing relations with the Taliban, and argues that Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI) has killed or imprisoned the Taliban leaders who were interested in peace and reconciliation with the Afghan government. It praises President Ghani for asking the Taliban to cut ties with all terrorist groups and Pakistan if they want to make genuine peace. (p 2, about 650 words in Pashto, PROCESSING)

2. Article by political activist Malalai Shinwari entitled "Afghan women will never reverse" condemns the Taliban regime in the 90s, and gives an assurance that Afghan women will not allow any political party or militant group to stop them from making democratic achievements. It stresses that the Afghan government should not compromise the country's national interests in any peace talks with its armed opponents. (p 5, about 1,200 words in Pashto, NPP)

3. Unattributed article entitled "Killing should be stopped in tribal areas" discusses the Pakistani army's cruel behavior towards ethnic Pashtuns in Pakistan's Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, saying the Islamabad administration should give clarifications about the recent spate of human rights violations in Pashtun-inhabited areas. (p 3, about 1,200 words in Pashto, NPP)

4. Unattributed article entitled "Delay in holding of Islamabad meeting unveils Taliban's prestige" argues that Pakistan does not care about the Taliban and this is why it allowed the US to kill or imprison prominent militant leaders after the international community came to Afghanistan in 2001. It comments on the cancellation of a Taliban-Pakistan meeting that was supposed to be held in Islamabad last week. (p 7, about 1,000 words in Pashto, NPP)

5. Article by Shah Wali Qarar Shinwari entitled "Discussion over next peaceful, national and consultative grand assembly; historical face of national and traditional grand assemblies in Afghanistan" is sure that the Afghan government will never compromise the constitution and the democratic achievements made by the Afghans during the past 18 years. It stresses that Taliban leaders should take part in the next consultative grand assembly due to be held in Kabul next month. (p 2, about 1,800 words in Pashto, NPP)

6. Article by Tamim entitled "Afghan government cannot accept concessions for enemy" urges the UN Security Council not to allow the Taliban leaders whose names are in the black to visit any country in the region and the world. It gives an assurance that the Afghan government will never hold talks with the insurgents who still believe in violence and barbarity. (p 2, about 1,500 words in Pashto, NPP)

Maseer (private)

1. Editorial entitled "What type of amendment to negotiating team?" praises US special envoy for Afghanistan reconciliation Zalmay Khalilzad for asking the Afghan government to form a comprehensive negotiating team to hold with Taliban representatives in Doha, Qatar. It urges Kabul not to insist on controversial issues, and stresses that any negotiating team should be headed by an impartial politician so that the Taliban are ready to negotiate. (p 2, about 600 words in Pashto, PROCESSING)

2. Article by Strategic Centre for Regional Studies entitled "Moscow conference; will intra-Afghan talks begin?" is not confident that Afghanistan will achieve lasting peace without regional countries' sincere cooperation, and stresses that political personalities should keep holding peace talks with the Taliban. It describes the next consultative grand assembly due to be held in Kabul next month as effective for reconciliation with the Taliban. (p 2, about 2,000 words in Pashto, NPP)

Sarkhat (private)

1. Editorial entitled "Afghan peace, golden swallow for Pakistan" argues that Pakistan is trying to sabotage the Afghan peace process by raising its political and military disputes with India, saying every Afghan national understands the fact that disputes between neighbouring countries cannot be linked with peace talks. It claims with confidence that the Afghan conflict will never end unless Pakistan comes under immense military and economic pressure. (p 2, about 600 words in Pashto, NPP)

2. Analysis entitled "City of turmoil; word that has never been put into action" is concerned about the presence of illegal armed individuals and arms caches in Kabul city, and praises acting interior minister Masud Andarabi for threatening former warlords who are still at large. It urges the ministries of interior affairs and national defence as well as the National Directorate of Security (NDS) to do everything to improve the security situation in big cities. (p 2, about 800 words in Dari, NPP)

3. Unattributed article entitled "Khalilzad's new role" accuses US special envoy for Afghanistan reconciliation Zalmay Khalilzad of making the peace process more complicated and controversial by forcing the Afghan government to change its tough stance against the Taliban. It accuses the US of playing an insincere role in peace talks with the Taliban. (p 2, about 1,200 words in Pashto, NPP)

4. Article by Sayed Khalid Sadat entitled "Saudi Arabia, Pakistan, and international jihad" comments on Saudi Arabia Crown Prince Mohammad Bin Salman Al Saud's recent Islamabad visit where he pledged to invest more than 20bn dollars in different sectors in Pakistan. It endorses the allegation that Pakistan is the main sponsor of terrorists in the world, saying Saudi Arabia is getting its political goals achieved in the region with the help of Pakistan. (p 3, about 1,200 words in Dari, NPP)

Shahadat weekly (affiliated with Arghandiwal-led Hezb-e Islami) 19 February

1. Editorial entitled "Need to adopt silent diplomacy on Afghan peace" accuses the US, Russia, Qatar, the United Arab Emirate, Pakistan, Iran, Saudi Arabia, and China of trying to make political use of the continuation and escalation of the Afghan conflict. It warns that Afghanistan will continue to experience a bloody war due to its immediate neighbours' insincerity and bad intentions. (pp 1, 4, about 700 words in Pashto, NPP)

2. Article by Faiz Mohammad Faiz entitled "We experience that stage of history again" praises the Afghan nation for defeating the Soviet forces in 1989, saying former jihadi leaders failed to discharge their duties and responsibilities after the Soviet withdrawal from the country. It urges political personalities, civil activists, and tribal leaders to set aside differences with the government and instead defend the country's national interests. (p 2, about 1,800 words in Dari, NPP)

3. Article by Mohammad Khalil entitled "Peace can tackle all misfortunes, but war is source of all adversities" urges the Taliban to accept Afghanistan's constitution in addition to holding direct talks with the government. It warns that neighbouring countries will keep the fires of war burning in Afghanistan if the international community abandons it in this sensitive situation. (p 2, about 1,800 words in Pashto, NPP)

Newspaper published in Herat

Etefaq-e Islam (state-run daily) 18 February

1. Local health officials said that a polio eradication campaign has been launched in Herat city, the capital of western Herat province, and Shindand District. (p 1, about 200 words in Dari, NPP)

2. Mohammad Dawud, deputy governor of Herat, has chaired a meeting with provincial councillors in his office. In the meeting, the deputy governor praised the provincial councillors for its outstanding performance and urged them to do everything to solve local people's problems. (p 1, about 250 words in Dari, NPP)

3. The department of agriculture, irrigation and animal husbandry in Herat says more than 5,000 saplings have been planted in different parts of the province this year. (p 4, about 150 words in Dari, NPP)

Source: As listed Source: Afghan press selection list in Dari and Pashto 20 Feb 19
